title: EPPS6356
text: Greetings everyone! Welcome to my personal website. This website is created as a part of the EPPS 6356 Data Visualization class (instructor Dr. Karl Ho) for Fall 2024 session at the University of Texas at Dallas.

title: Umme Kulsum
text:
Umme Kulsum is a 3rd year PhD student in the Geospatial Information Sciecnces program under the School of Economics Political and Policy Sciences at the University of Texas at Dallas. She is currently focusing on exploring Human-Rhino Conflicts in Chitwan National Park, Nepal. Her primary interests are Geographic Information System (GIS), Remote Sensing (RS) and Human-environment Interaction.

Education
Doctor of Philosophy: (Ongoing) Geospatial Information Sciences Program, School of Economics, Political and Policy Sciences, The University of Texas at Dallas
Master of Science: Dept. of Geography and Environment, Jagannath University, Bangladesh
Bachelor of Science: Dept. of Geography and Environment, Jagannath University, Bangladesh


Work
Instructor (May 2024-Aug. 2024): Geospatial Information Sciences Program, The University of Texas at Dallas
Course:

GEOG 2303 World Regional Geography

Teaching Assistant (Aug. 2022-Present): Geospatial Information Sciences Program, The University of Texas at Dallas
Courses:

GISC 6381 Geographic Information Systems Fundamentals; Supervisor: Dr. Yongwan Chun (Fall-2022 and Fall-2023)
GISC 4382 Applied Geographic Information Systems; Supervisor: Dr. Yongwan Chun (Spring-2023 and Spring-2024)

Research Officer: Unnayan Shamannay (Non-profit research organization), Dhaka, Bangladesh
Intern: Ark Foundation (Non-profit research organization), Dhaka, Bangladesh

title: Assignment 1
text:
1. anscombe01.R

## Data Visualization
## Objective: Identify data or model problems using visualization

## Fancy version (per help file)

ff <- y ~ x
mods <- setNames(as.list(1:4), paste0("lm", 1:4))

# Plot using for loop
for(i in 1:4) {
  ff[2:3] <- lapply(paste0(c("y","x"), i), as.name)
  ## or   ff[[2]] <- as.name(paste0("y", i))
  ##      ff[[3]] <- as.name(paste0("x", i))
  mods[[i]] <- lmi <- lm(ff, data = anscombe)
  print(anova(lmi))
}

# Preparing for the plots
op <- par(mfrow = c(2, 2), mar = 0.1+c(4,4,1,1), oma =  c(0, 0, 2, 0))

# Plot charts using for loop
for(i in 1:4) {
  ff[2:3] <- lapply(paste0(c("y","x"), i), as.name)
  plot(ff, data = anscombe, col = "red", pch = 21, bg = "orange", cex = 1.2,
       xlim = c(3, 19), ylim = c(3, 13))
  abline(mods[[i]], col = "blue")
}
mtext("Anscombe's 4 Regression data sets", outer = TRUE, cex = 1.5)







par(op)

title: Assignment 1

3. Fall Color
Color: #ffcd50
To me, fall is more yellow than orange.

title: Assignment 1
text:
4. Critique

This figure was collected from the article named “Mapping understory invasive plant species with field and remotely sensed data in Chitwan, Nepal” by Dai et. al, (2020). This particular chart shows box plots of GV (green vegetation) and Shade fractions between presence (green) and community forest background pixels (orange).

Critique of the Chart:
a. The colors are too bright.
b. The reference line text is larger than the text inside the chart.
c. Sectioning of the chart makes it easier to interpret.
d. Good use of empty spaces with text in both of the sections
e. Green is not a colorblind friendly color.
f. The font is uniform.
Reference:
Dai, J., Roberts, D. A., Stow, D. A., An, L., Hall, S. J., Yabiku, S. T., & Kyriakidis, P. C. (2020). Mapping understory invasive plant species with field and remotely sensed data in Chitwan, Nepal. Remote Sensing of Environment, 250, 112037. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2020.112037

title: Assignment 2
text:
1. Paul Murrell Code Modification

### Paul Murrell's R examples (selected)

## Start plotting from basics 
# Note the order
plot(pressure, pch=19)  # Can you change pch? 

# The pch was changed to 19 from 16
text(150, 600, 
     "Pressure (mm Hg)\nversus\nTemperature (Celsius)")







#  Examples of standard high-level plots 
#  In each case, extra output is also added using low-level 
#  plotting functions.
# 

# Setting the parameter (3 rows by 2 cols)
par(mfrow=c(3, 2))

# Scatterplot
# Note the incremental additions

x <- c(0.5, 2, 4, 8, 12, 16)
y1 <- c(1, 1.3, 1.9, 3.4, 3.9, 4.8)
y2 <- c(4, .8, .5, .45, .4, .3)

# Setting label orientation, margins c(bottom, left, top, right) & text size
par(las=1, mar=c(4, 4, 2, 4), cex=.7) 
plot.new()
plot.window(range(x), c(0, 6))
lines(x, y1)
lines(x, y2)
points(x, y1, pch=16, cex=1) # Try different cex value?  
points(x, y2, pch=21, bg="lightblue1", cex=2)  # Different background color
par(col="gray50", fg="gray50", col.axis="gray50")
axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4)) # What is the first number standing for?
# The horizontal axis
axis(2, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
axis(4, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
box(bty="u")
mtext("Travel Time (s)", side=1, line=2, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Travel", side=2, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Second", side=4, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), col="black", fg="black", col.axis="black")

# Histogram
# Random data
Y <- rnorm(50)
# Make sure no Y exceed [-3.5, 3.5]
Y[Y < -3.5 | Y > 3.5] <- NA # Selection/set range
x <- seq(-3.5, 3.5, .1)
dn <- dnorm(x)
par(mar=c(4.5, 4.1, 3.1, 0))
hist(Y, breaks=seq(-3.5, 3.5), ylim=c(0, 0.5), 
     col="gray80", freq=FALSE)
lines(x, dnorm(x), lwd=2)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))

# Barplot
par(mar=c(2, 3.1, 2, 2.1)) 
midpts <- barplot(VADeaths, 
                  col=gray(0.1 + seq(1, 9, 2)/11), 
                  names=rep("", 4))
mtext(sub(" ", "\n", colnames(VADeaths)),
      at=midpts, side=1, line=0.5, cex=0.5)
text(rep(midpts, each=5), apply(VADeaths, 2, cumsum) - VADeaths/2,
     VADeaths, 
     col=rep(c("white", "black"), times=3:2), 
     cex=0.8)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))  

# Boxplot
par(mar=c(3, 4.1, 2, 0))
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 - 0.2,
        subset= supp == "VC", col="white",
        xlab="",
        ylab="tooth length", ylim=c(0,35))
mtext("Vitamin C dose (mg)", side=1, line=2.5, cex=0.8)
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth, add = TRUE,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 + 0.2,
        
        subset= supp == "OJ")
legend(1.5, 9, c("Ascorbic acid", "Orange juice"), 
       fill = c("white", "gray"), 
       bty="n")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))

# Persp
x <- seq(-10, 10, length= 30)
y <- x
f <- function(x,y) { r <- sqrt(x^2+y^2); 10 * sin(r)/r }
z <- outer(x, y, f)
z[is.na(z)] <- 1
# 0.5 to include z axis label
par(mar=c(0, 0.5, 0, 0), lwd=0.5)
persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, 
      expand = 0.5)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), lwd=1)

# Piechart
par(mar=c(0, 2, 1, 2), xpd=FALSE, cex=0.5)
pie.sales <- c(0.12, 0.3, 0.26, 0.16, 0.04, 0.12)
names(pie.sales) <- c("Blueberry", "Cherry",
                      "Apple", "Boston Cream", "Other", "Vanilla")
pie(pie.sales, col = gray(seq(0.3,1.0,length=6)))

title: Assignment 2
section: 2. Exercise: Can you generate these charts individually? Try these functions
text:
2. Exercise: Can you generate these charts individually? Try these functions

# Load necessary packages
library(ggplot2)
library(rgl)
library(readxl)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# Load data
hpindex <- read_excel("/Users/ummekulsum/Library/CloudStorage/Box-Box/WorkingDirectory/Fall 2024/EPPS6356/Assignments/hpindex.xlsx")

New names:
• `` -> `...4`

# Filter 
HPI_filter <- (hpindex[, c("Country", 'Continent', "Population(t)", "Life_Expectancy(y)", "Wellbeing", "tCO2e", "HPI", "CO2_threshold(tCO2e)", "GDP_per_capita")])

# i. par() and iv. axis() function
par(mfrow = c(1, 2), family = "Palatino",
    cex.main = 0.8, cex.lab = 0.8, font.main = 2, font.lab = 1, font.axis = 1)
plot(HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`, HPI_filter$tCO2e, pch = 16, col = "steelblue",  main = "Carbon Footprint \nvs \nLife Expectancy ",
     xlab = "Life Expectancy in years", ylab = "Carbon Footprint in tons of CO2 equivalent",
     ylim = c(-5, 50), 
     yaxt = 'n', yaxs = 'i')
axis(2, at = seq(0 , 40, by = 10), labels = c('0', '', '20', '', '40' ))
plot(HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`, HPI_filter$GDP_per_capita/1e6, pch = 19, col = "violetred1", 
     main = "GDP \n vs\n Life Expectancy", xlab = "Life Expectancy in years", 
     ylab = "GDP per Capita (in Millions $)",
     ylim = c(-0.01, 0.14), 
     yaxt = "n", yaxs = "i")
axis(2, at = seq(0, 0.12, by = 0.02), labels = c("0", "", "0.04", "", "0.08", "", "0.12"))







par(mfrow = c(1, 1))  # Reset to default layout

## ix. Boxplot
par(mfrow = c(1, 1), family = "Palatino", cex.main = 1.2, cex.lab = 1.1)

# Boxplot: Population per Continent
boxplot(HPI_filter$`Population(t)`/1e3 ~ HPI_filter$Continent, 
        xlab = "Population (in Million)", 
        ylab = "Continent", 
        ylim = c(0, 350),
        main = "Boxplot of Population per Continent", 
        col = "orange", 
        horizontal = TRUE, 
        las = 1)







# hist() function 
par(mfrow = c(1, 1), family = "Palatino", 
    cex.main = 1.2, cex.lab = 1.2, font.main = 2, font.lab = 1, font.axis = 1)
hist(na.omit(HPI_filter$HPI), 
     main = "Histogram of Happy Index",
     xlab = "Happy Index", 
     col = "lightblue2", 
     prob = TRUE)
lines(density(na.omit(HPI_filter$HPI)), col = "black", lwd = 2)







# ii. lines(), iii. points(), v, box(), x. legend() and vi. text()
par(mfrow = c(1, 1), family = "Palatino",
    cex.main = 1.3, cex.lab = 1.1, font.main = 2, font.lab = 1, font.axis = 1)
plot(HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`, HPI_filter$GDP_per_capita, 
     type = "n", main = "Life Expectancy vs GDP", 
     xlab = "Life Expectancy (years)", 
     ylab = "GDP per Capita ($)")

# points and lines
lines(HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`, HPI_filter$GDP_per_capita, col = "lightgreen")
points(HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`, HPI_filter$GDP_per_capita, pch = 16, col = "blue")

# box
box(lwd = 2, col = "black")

#  custom text
text(70, 100000, "High GDP Region", col = "Black", cex = 1.2, cex.main = 2)

# legend
legend("topleft", legend = c("GDP Data"), col = c("red"), pch = c(16), lty = c(1), lwd = 2)







# xi. persp() and xiii. pie() 

# 3D Perspective Plot: Wellbeing vs GDP per Capita and Life Expectancy
x <- HPI_filter$`Life_Expectancy(y)`
y <- HPI_filter$GDP_per_capita
z <- HPI_filter$Wellbeing

# Creating a grid for the perspective plot
x_grid <- seq(min(x, na.rm = TRUE), max(x, na.rm = TRUE), length = 30)
y_grid <- seq(min(y, na.rm = TRUE), max(y, na.rm = TRUE), length = 30)

# fuction for z grid
z_function <- function(x, y) {
  z_val <- (x + y) / 2
  return(z_val)
}

z_grid <- outer(x_grid, y_grid, FUN = z_function)

# 3D perspective plot
par(mfrow = c(1, 1), family = "Palatino",
    cex.main = 1.3, cex.lab = 0.8, font.main = 2, font.lab = 1, font.axis = 1)
persp(x_grid, y_grid, z_grid, theta = 30, phi = 20, col = "lightblue", 
      main = "3D Perspective Plot: Wellbeing vs Life Expectancy and GDP", 
      xlab = "Life Expectancy", ylab = "GDP per Capita", zlab = "Wellbeing")







# Calculating average HPI per continent
HPI_avg_per_continent <- HPI_filter %>%
  group_by(Continent) %>%
  summarize(avg_HPI = mean(HPI, na.rm = TRUE))

#Spectral color palette
spectral_colors <- brewer.pal(length(HPI_avg_per_continent$avg_HPI), "Spectral")

# percentage
pct <- round(HPI_avg_per_continent$avg_HPI / sum(HPI_avg_per_continent$avg_HPI) * 100)
labels <- paste0(pct, "%")  

# Pie Chart
pie(HPI_avg_per_continent$avg_HPI, 
    labels = labels,  
    main = "Average HPI per Continent", 
    col = spectral_colors)

# Legend
legend("topright", legend = HPI_avg_per_continent$Continent, 
       fill = spectral_colors, title = "Continents")

title: Prepare for Class 4
section: 2. Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science
text:
2. Hadley Wickham: Data Visualization and Data Science
Dr. Wickham introduced tidyverse, which is the combination of ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr purr packages.
The main points of the video is data visualization. However, data preparation was also emphasized to get a good visualization. Tidy data is important to get a good visualization. HE demonstrated how he cleaned and arranged data for the purpose of creating a chart. The famous GDP per Capita vs Life Expectancy chart of Hans Rosling was recreated using ggplot2 and a demonstration for how to customize the chart and make it an animation was also given.
Some points made by Dr. Wickham
Power of Code

it may look overwhelming but it has a lot of opportunity because it is basically text
it is readable.
it is reproducible. One can reproduce the same thing with a different dataset and do not have to think about missing any steps.
